Steely Danish dissects the Dan's complex world

Steely Danish dives into the complicated world of Steely Dan with its tribute show

Steely Danish dissects the Dan's complex world

Jeffrey Lee Puckett, jpuckett@courier-journal.com 10:24 a.m. EST December 22, 2014

Steely Danish

Story Highlights

  • STEELY DANISH %u2014 A TRIBUTE TO THE MUSIC OF STEELY DAN
  • WHEN: 9 p.m. Saturday
  • WHERE: Mercury Ballroom, 611 S. Fourth St.
  • COST: $12
CONNECT 6 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Steely Dan's Donald Fagen and Walter Becker are notorious for writing incredibly difficult music, at least by pop and rock standards.

They use elements of jazz and classical, orchestrating an overall sound built on very specific voicings, in which they use a collection of instruments to explore pitches within chords. Their repeated and varied use of the mu major chord, a major triad with an added major 2nd, is what gives the band such a distinctive sound.

Yeah, I don't understand most of that, either. It was all gleaned from research, so thanks, Internet! I also asked Danny Kiely, because he should know.

Kiely is a founding member of Steely Danish, which performs Saturday at the Mercury Ballroom. The Louisville collective — 11 members and counting — is a Steely Dan tribute band, and that is a long way removed from a Ramones tribute band.

COURIER-JOURNAL

New movies opening in Louisville theaters Christmas week

"Generally, their music doesn't, I guess, comport with the usual harmonic vocabulary that most rock and pop bands use," said Kiely, who plays bass and sings. "It can get really difficult and confusing to memorize that music."

Apparently that's also true for the actual Steely Dan. A friend of Kiely's attended a Steely Dan soundcheck when they last played in Louisville, and he was surprised to spot a book of lyric and chord change reminders perched on Fagen's keyboard.

Steely Danish knows the feeling. When the band formed in 2011 for a Rudyard Kipling benefit show, plans for having a couple of rehearsals turned into almost daily rehearsals for two weeks. Kiely, an accomplished jazz musicians and Dan fan, was astounded by the music's complexity.

"Their chord progressions are almost always not what you might think they are," he said. "There's no real reference point ... and the usual set of chords doesn't apply."

Ironically, Dan haters often cite the band's smoothness as a detriment. Kiely has a hard time understanding how music so intricate can sound smooth to some when all he hears is a series of challenges. But at this point, he said, he doesn't worry about dissecting or explaining Steely Dan to non-believers.

"It takes all of your time to play it," he said, "much less analyze it."

Jeffrey Lee Puckett can be reached at (502) 582-4160, jpuckett@courier-journal.com and on Twitter, @JLeePuckett.

STEELY DANISH — A TRIBUTE TO THE MUSIC OF STEELY DAN

WHEN: 9 p.m. Saturday

WHERE: Mercury Ballroom, 611 S. Fourth St.

COST: $12
